data.event: The first white settlement in the area now known as Davenport was in 1838 when the U.S. military set up Fort Davenport during the Second Seminole War, about 12 miles north of the present site of Davenport.

event.title: 1838 when the U.S. military set up

data.event: The first white settlement in the area now known as Davenport was in 1838 when the U.S. military set up Fort Davenport during the Second Seminole War, about 12 miles north of the present site of Davenport.
The fort only lasted a few years.

event.title: recorded on a U.S. Army survey of 1849

data.event: The settlement was first known as Horse Creek, for the creek first recorded on a U.S. Army survey of 1849 which flows past the site to enter Snell Creek and eventually Lake Hatchineha in the Kissimmee River system.

event.title: was established at Horse Creek in 1884

data.event: A post office was established at Horse Creek in 1884, and the name of the post office was changed to Davenport in 1886.
